content.description: This is a classic sandbag. Climb slightly overhanging, thin fingers to hands up top. Start off the top of the obvious block in the corridor. The flare makes for good feet in the crack, all the edges on the outside just break away. The name is making fun of a couple of spraymasters who were sandbagged on the line and then laughed at because they couldn't even do women's work.
content.protection: #4 Zero through #2.5 Friend.  You can also get a big hands or fist piece for the easy top section. There is a fixed nut at start and coldhuts up top.
content.location: As you approach EOTRR as per the description, you will see a slightly flared splitter finger crack facing you (on the west side of EOTRR), the bottom hidden behind another part of the formation.  It has greenish yellow lichen prettying it up, a pod near the top, and a horizontal crack intersects the left side near the bottom.  You have to scramble up some slabs and into a narrow gully to get to it.  Starts off a wedged boulder in the gully.

content.description: Start off of a boulder to climb the left of twin hand cracks. Switch from the left crack to the right crack when the left crack peters out. Walk off right.
content.protection: Hand-size pieces to a gear belay.
content.location: Go up the hill right at the end of the road. The route is on the right hand side of the rock and just left of a right-leaning hand & fist crack.

content.description:
Follow the right-leaning fist crack just to the left of "

Two of a Kind

". A fun, short outing with a wide, fist jam crux. Bigger hands will help with the wide fists. Between the wideness you will find good jams. Worth doing if you are in the area.
content.location: The obvious, right-leaning crack on the north side of the east face.

content.description:
After a strenuous first move (consider stemming to the start of Inside Flush), climb vertical hands and fists past several horizontals to the top of the detached pillar. Belay, then scramble across the uppermost chockstone to the top of

Inside Flush

and

Two of a Kind

(feels very exposed, might be 5.2 or so).
content.location:
This is inside the large chimney formed between a detached pillar and the bulk of End Of The Road Rocks. Climb an obvious crack on the detached pillar inside the chimney.

Scramble to the

Two of a Kind's

bolts, and rappel with a single 50m rope.

climbs.name: Inside Flush
climbs.fa: FFA Ernie Johnson and Skip Harper in '93

content.description:
A fun big hands to fists to wide crack up a nearly vertical wall.  Start from a ledge inside the corridor and climb a crack as it steadily widens to offwidth just before a ledge (easier for bigger hands).  Getting onto the ledge is the crux.  You can either continue up an offwidth/squeeze straight up, or exit right onto the finish

Two of a Kind

.  Either way, belay in the alcove behind the squeeze.  It is highly recommended, if you do the squeeze, to either run it out, back clean, or use Big bros, to prevent a snag while pulling the rope.
content.protection: SR to 5", with a couple spares in the big hands-fists size.  I didn't place anything smaller than a #1 camalot, including the anchor.
content.location:
From the base of

Two of a Kind

, look left into a corridor.  Inside Flush is the hand crack that passes to the right of the big chockstone.

content.description: This route starts with a steep section of hands off the deck and gradually widens to fists.  It ends on a couple of OW moves to a lieback flake.  Continue up the moderate slab.
content.location: It is a bit convoluted to find this line.... It lies behind End of the Road Rock, we found it when descending.  It's obvious as you near the trees on the walk-off.
